Project Development Objective: DON'T PUB DROPPED  Based on the experience of the Bogota Urban Services I, it is proposed that the project would be composed of the following components: A. Improved mobility. This component includes actions for continued expansion of the second phase of the Transmilenio system and continued improved access to public transport. It comprises the following activities: (i) construction of busways, (ii) construction and rehabilitation of feeder routes which connect neighborhoods to the Transmilenio system as part of an integrated system; (iii) construction of bicycle paths and sidewalks as part of non-motorized transport facilities; and (iv) measures for improving public transport, road safety and traffic administration in the city of Bogot. B. Urban upgrading. This component is designed to support the activities of the Programa de Mejoramiento Integral de Barrios (PMIB), which is the District's urban upgrading program derived from the POT and PD. CVP is the institution in charge of coordinating the infrastructure works and social activities in selected low-income areas located in 12 UPZs. The infrastructure works comprise: (i) planning and neighborhood plot legalization; (ii) construction of storm water drainage systems, water and sewerage systems (iii) construction and rehabilitation of access roads; (iv) resettlement of population located in high risk areas, including flood plains; (v) construction and rehabilitation of public space and community services; (vi) improvement of environmental conditions; and (vii) technical assistance for home improvement and land tittling activities. The  social activities associated with the physical works include: (i) promoting citizen culture; (ii) strengthening social organizations; and (iv) assisting vulnerable population. C. Institutional strenghtening and Technical Assistance. This component is aimed at improving the performance of the institutions in delivering urban services through activities that will guarantee the social, environmental and financial sustainability of the works undertaken by the proposed project. The activities include technical assistance for District institutions working in areas ranging from transport, housing and environmental management sectors, to planning and financing urban development activities. Specifically, this component will support equipment, training and consulting services.

DON'T PUB DROPPED  The proposed operation will contribute to reducing poverty and inequality by improving social and economic opportunities, and the human development and well-being in IP populations, through: (a) empowering IP communities and strengthening governance by building capacity at the community and municipal level in participatory decision-making; (b) using the skills, social capital and experience of the communities, municipalities and CDI to support cross-sectoral integration of development actions at the CDI and municipal level, resulting in integrated development plans for the IP population, and improving the relevance, efficiency, and bundling of other non-project services; (c) supporting creation of assets to provide basic services identified on a participatory basis; and (c) integrating environmental sustainability and IP culture considerations into development actions.

Project Name: Ensuring SME Participation in International Trade
Project Development Objective:
The project development objective (PDO) is to increase the competitiveness of Salvadoran small and medium enterprises (SMEs) as well as of companies with strategic linkages with SMEs, by means of supporting innovation and technology adoption, quality enhancements and exports. Thus, the main expected beneficiaries of the project are SMEs and their strategic partners. Other beneficiaries include public and private institutions that provide technology or quality services to the private sector  ranging from universities and public R&D centers to testing laboratories and quality certification consultants  and the units within the Ministry of the Economy in charge of implementing the countrys policies in the areas of quality and innovation. Indeed, while ESPRIT will focus on co-financing innovation, quality enhancing and export projects developed by SMEs and associated companies, it will also provide complementary support to the expansion of the supply of technology and quality services for private firms, and the strengthening of the institutions in charge of El Salvadors technology and quality policies.
  The achievement of the PDO will be measured against the following main project outcomes: (i) increased innovation and technology adoption by the SMEs and associated companies supported by the project; (ii) increased compliance with international quality standards and regulations by project supported SMEs and their partners; and (iii) increased exports and increased sales to large exporters by the SMEs supported by the project. 
 The following are the key performance indicators to assess progress towards the PDO. 
 (i)	Number of firms that introduced new products and/or processes through ESPRIT-supported innovation projects: 50 by the end of the second year and 200 by the end of the project. 
 (ii)	Number of firms supported by the project that received internationally recognized quality certifications: 20 by the end of the second year and 80 by the end of the project. 
 (iii)	New exports generated by firms supported by the project: US$ 7 million by the end of the second year and US$ 31 million by the end of the project.

The objective is to enhance access of targeted rural populations to local services by improving the quality of the rural road network in selected municipalities and in a sustainable fashion, establishing effective methods for the maintenance of this network, and developing the institutional capacity necessary.

The objective is to improve the protection, conservation and sustainable development of indigenous lands with respect to indigenous peoples and natural resources.  A new operation Brazil Indigenous Peoples Sustainable Development would be prepared with the client, Fundacao Nacional do Indio (FUNAI).  The new operation would build on previous operations especially the Pilot Program to Conserve the Brazilian Rain Forest Indigenous Lands Project that helped legalize 40 million hectares of indigenous lands inn the Amazon. This follow on operation would focus on addressing two of the main challenges that still are critical for the futures of indigenous peoples in Brazil: (1) How best to protect and sustainably manage their lands and natural resources, and (2) how best to protect and promote the well-being of indigenous people to both ensure their welfare and to help them determine their owns paths toward economic change cosnsistent with their socio-cultural values. The new operation would be financed by an investment loan from the World Bank (currently estimated at $40 m.), a grant from KfW/Germany (currently estimated at $10 m.), and counterpart funds (currently estimated at 40 percent). Although still in the identification phase, a recent brainstorming on the new operation preliminarily identified the following components: (1) Institutional Strengthening; (2) Improving Public Policies and Interinstitutional Links; (3) Territorial Protection; and (4) Promotion of Sustainable Development.

The objective is to contribute to the attainment of a defined reduction in fatalities and injuries due to road traffic crashes, through strengthening the institutional framework and management of road safety activities, together with targeted investment on defined pilot corridors in Peru.  This project will consist of preparation activities for a new road safety project in Peru that will assist the government to implement its National Road Safety Plan. The components are envisioned to include capacity building, institutional strengthening, and some infrastructure works to improve road safety. The project will employ a multi-sectoral approach and build upon government's efforts to develop a '2nd generation' road safety project; with involvement of various stakeholders (health, education, interior). Some of the immediate priorities identified are the development of advanced monitoring and evaluation systems, creation of regional safety committees, improved compliance mechanisms and fleet management studies. The project is expected to benefit from grant resources from the Global Road Safety Facility, through which, access will also be provided to innovative international initiatives such as iRAP, IRTAD and ITPN.

Project Name: Saving Glaciers: Artisanal Industry Aims to Stop the Melt and Save Water
Project Development Objective: Climate change is melting tropical glaciers. Task DescriptionThe proposed Carbon Finance Transaction involves the delivery of and payment for Emission Reductions (ERs) between M exico  s National Forestry Commission (CONAFOR, for its acronyms in Spanish) as the Program Entity and the World Bank as Trustee o f the Forest Carbon Partnership Facility  s (FCPF) Carbon Fund. It does not involve the direct financing of any of the underlying activities generating such ERs. Mexico  s proposed ER Program is part of the Carbon Fund pipelineof ER Programs and would be among  the first of such Programs worldwide to receive payments based on verified REDD+ results. 
The proposed Development Objective is t o promote the adoption of sustainable land management practices and reduce greenhouse gas emissions from deforestation and forest de gradation (REDD) in selected States in Mexico.Board Schedule Comments

Project Development Objective: The Tarucani Project consists of a power plant of 49 MW capacity (35MW net power), that utilizes water from the Majes irrigation project that uses the water resources of the Colca River, which are collected at the Tutti gate and will produce an average net annual generation of 375 GWh. The Majes project was built for irrigation and electricity generation purposes, and uses a 100 kilometer long system of tunnels and canals that have a capacity of 34 m3/s. The project aims at supporting Brazil's program to help low income households to have access to shelter and basic housing services. The project will include two components. The first will support the design and implementation of a federal system of housing subsidies based on the recent experience of the PSH and as part of the recently approved National housing Fund.  The second component will support the design and implementation of the National Upgrading Program based on a system of block-grants negotiated between the federal and local governments.  The SWAP system will follow the design tested under the Municipal Health program. TO BE DROPPED - REASON This project was designed as part of the Housing DPL series.  The bulk of preparation funds was spent in FY04 for the initial design, which led to the DPL..  Expenditures during the past 2 FYs were used to maintain a policy dialog in a ministry that had high amounts of staff turn-over.  The project  is no longer needed as the housing sector  figures prominently in Government's PAC( thanks in part to the success of the strong policy dialog and DPL).  A new TA project for broader support to PAC implementation may be identified.
The project will support the Government of Peru to implement its housing sector strategy.

The objectives are to (a) assist with measures in the energy sector that will allow it to reduce its dependence on imported oil; and (b) employ both short- and longer-term options involving both investment and technical assistance.  The overall objective of the project is to assist Guatemala put in place measures in the energy sector that will allow it to reduce its dependence on imported oil. The project would employ both short- and longer-term options involving both investment and technical assistance.  Among the short-term options are: (i) increased regional trade, (ii) power system management improvements to reduce losses, (iii) operation and maintenance measures to increase load factors, and (iv) demand-side management (energy efficiency) measures for residential, commercial, industrial, and agricultural sectors.  Among the longer-term options are: (i) repowering of existing power capacity, such as hydropower rehabilitation and high-efficiency bagasse cogeneration, (ii) transmission investments, both domestic and regional, and (iii) investment in new generation capacity, including coal, hydro, LNG, geothermal and other renewables.  Technical assistance will also be included, such as: (i) power system planning to promote least-cost investments, including capital-intensive, (ii) policy measures to enhance the use of domestic and renewable energy resources, and (iii) regulatory measures to attract private sector investment within the context of a national plan.

Project Name: Improving Access and Quality of Basic Health Care Services
Project Development Objective:
The Project Development Objective of the proposed project is to support the GOH in expanding and sustaining the use of basic health care services among rural, remote and poor populations. The project will support the increase in quality of these services as measured through the performance indicators. This project aims to diminish service access inequities and to reduce the risks that contribute to infant, child, and maternal mortality.
  In addition to the objectives and indicators listed above, the proposed project aims to respond to epidemiological emergencies and strengthen surveillance. Success in achieving this objective will be assessed by measuring: (i) the number of sentinel units implementing syndromatic surveillance; (ii) updated National Surveillance guidelines; (iii) percentage of municipal surveillance units compliant with revised surveillance guidelines, receiving a satisfactory or better rating; and (iv) number of epidemiological bulletins produced per year by the public Health Surveillance Laboratory Network.

Dropped Andes Adaptation Impact of Climate Change in Water Resource
Project Development Objective:
The project has been designed to tackle the challenge of adaptation to climate change on selected sectors from a technology transfer, knowledge exchange and regional collaboration angle. Based on previous experience in the region, the project will select those technologies and approaches that have been proved valid elsewhere and try to adapt and replicate them in the other countries, according to the special needs and gaps of each one of them.

Specifically, the proposed objective of this project is to generate tools and knowledge to enable governments to promote resilient management of their water resources through the inclusion of climate change impacts into policy, planning and on the ground investments on selected sectors, and to promote south-south learning, collaboration andtechnology transfer.

Project Name: Dropped Sustainable Forest Management in Atalaya, Ucayali.
Project Development Objective:
The High Level Objective of Perus Forest Investment Plan (PIP), which is expected to generate a transformative impact within the next 10-15 years, is to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions produced by deforestation and forest degradation, and enhance carbon reserves in sustainable forest landscapes, thereby helping to reach the national target of Declining net emissions to equivalent to zero in the category of Land Use, Land-Use Change and Forestry by . 2021. To achieve this objective the PIP is expected to generate two types of co-benefits: (i) reduce poverty of indigenous communities and other local populations, under a gender equality approach, by increasing income form management of sustainable forest landscapes and productive agroforestry mosaics; and (ii) reduce the loss of biodiversity and maintenance of forest ecosystem services. 

The Project Development Objective is to improve the capacity of forest communities and government agencies to manage forest resources sustainably, strengthen forest tenure rights and enhance forest governance leading to reduce GHG emissions from deforestation and forest degradation in the Atalaya Province.

Project Name: Improving the Management of the National Social Registry (SINAFO)
Project Development Objective:
The project development objective is to make Perus National Targeting System more inclusive, dynamic, and integrated for use by tar geted social programs. 

The PDO includes the adoption of several concepts already within Perus National Targeting System. Inclusiv e means ensuring that all poor and vulnerable households are included in the National Household Registry (RNH), the primary registry  used to target social programs. Dynamic refers to the need to ensure socioeconomic classification (SEC) and household composition a re updated regularly in the RNH. Integrated refers to the merging of data on households needs with data on availability of social p rograms and other administrative databases for implementing social policy.

Project Development Objective: The two-part Project Development Objective (PDO) is to support OSE in (i) improving the efficiency of water supply operations; and ( ii) pilot innovative technologies for improved resilience.
The Project Development Objective is to reduce wastewater pollution and strengthen the capacity of the participating institutions to  manage wastewater treatment systems in La Paz and Tarija.
Improve the efficiency and reliability of regional cargo and passenger ferry operations in the Kingstown Port.

Project Development Objective: The objective of the project is to protect income and mitigate the risks of damaging human capital of poor families with children an d youth.

Project Name: Strengthening the Social Protection System in Chile
Project Development Objective: To support the Government of Chile increasing the efficiency, effectiveness and inclusiveness of the social protection system.

Project Name: Mexico Increase Womens Access to Economic Opportunities and Promote Gender-Informed Sustainable Productivity Growth DPL
